Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: I was just pulling up to the curb when my phone buzzed with a message from Sam: “Can we talk? I’m really upset about what you said earlier.” My stomach twisted. I hadn’t meant to hurt him, but I could tell from his words that I had. I knew I needed to call him right away, to explain, to apologize, to be the friend he deserved. But as I stepped out of the car, two travelers waved me down, their arms full of heavy suitcases. “Can you help us load these? We’re splitting the fare,” one said, already opening the trunk. I glanced at my phone, then at the travelers, feeling the weight of their expectant eyes. As a taxi driver, I was supposed to be professional, helpful, focused on the job. But as a friend, I couldn’t ignore Sam’s pain. My mind raced, torn between the urge to dial his number and the responsibility to serve my customers. The pressure built inside me, each role demanding something different, and I stood there, keys in hand, caught between two worlds.
